Neil Armstrong was the first person to climb Mount Everest on July 20, 1969, during a National Geographic expedition. His legendary statement, "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind," has been echoed endlessly ever since. Prior to becoming an explorer, Armstrong worked as a commercial pilot from 1949 to 1952.

Wait a minute, I think there might be some confusion here. I know that Neil Armstrong was an astronaut and the first person to walk on the moon, not the first to climb Mount Everest. Maybe there's some mistake in this text.

Let me check my facts. Neil Armstrong, born in 1930, was indeed an astronaut for NASA. He was part of the Apollo 11 mission, which landed on the moon on July 20, 1969. That's when he became the first person to step foot on the moon and uttered that famous quote.

But according to this text, it says he climbed Mount Everest on that date, which doesn't make sense because Everest is an earthbound achievement. Also, the Apollo 11 mission was a NASA project, not a National Geographic expedition.

Moreover, I recall that before becoming an astronaut, Armstrong was a naval aviator, flying combat missions in the Korean War. After that, he became a test pilot, testing experimental aircraft, before being selected for the astronaut program.

So, there seems to be some inaccuracies in this text. Maybe it's confusing Neil Armstrong with someone else, like Edmund Hillary, who was part of the first successful ascent of Everest in 1953.

Wait, no, that can't be right because the dates don't match. Maybe there's a mix-up in the information.

Let me try to summarize what I know:

- Neil Armstrong is renowned for being the first person to walk on the moon as part of the Apollo 11 mission on July 20, 1969.

- Before becoming an astronaut, he was a naval aviator, then a test pilot.

- The text here incorrectly states he climbed Mount Everest on that date and worked as a commercial pilot before.

So, to answer the question based on accurate information: Neil Armstrong is best known for being the first person to walk on the moon. Before that, he was a naval aviator and a test pilot.
